article.head: Climate Action Note – State of the climate

text.p: Humanity’s use of fossil fuels has caused a climate emergency - ‘a code red for the planet’ according to UN SG Antonio Guterres. It’s devastating consequences are threatening our lives, economy, health and food systems - and extreme weather events are already wrecking havoc across the world. We are far from securing the global temperature rise safely below 1.5°C as promised in the Paris Agreement.
The UNEP Climate Dashboard shows you the global state of the climate emergency and its development.

article.title: Emissions
article.head: GHG emissions are choking our world and changing our climate

text.p: Global temperatures are linked to the concentration of greenhouse gases (GHG) in our atmosphere and we are heading for a catastrophic rise in excess of 3°C this century. To limit this to 1.5°C, as promised in the Paris Agreement, we need to cut emissions by 30 gigatones annually by 2030. That means cutting emissions from transport and industry, managing land and resources more efficiently, building smart cities and curbing deforestation and food waste.

article.title: Per capita
article.head: Individual emissions vary wildly; the wealthy emit the most

text.p: We all emit GHG during the cause of our lives. But some people emit a lot more than others. The world’s wealthiest 1 percent emit more than twice the emissions of the poorest half combined. As developing countries grow their economies, they need financial assistance and technical support to transition to low-carbon and resilient strategies. We can reduce emissions while growing the economy. The energy sector alone can cut emissions by 12.5 gigatonnes annually by switching to renewable energy and using its power more efficiently.

article.title: Trends
article.head: Some countries are making progress but all nations need to step up

text.p: In 2019, total GHG emissions, including land-use change, reached a new high of 59.1 GtCO2e. This is way beyond the Paris Agreement goals of limiting global warming to 1.5°C. And, we have the technological solutions to do it, including renewable energy, green hydrogen and modern bioenergy. Government subsidies and support could be directed to push towards low-carbon and green policies.
